etymologies: late Middle English: from Latin separabilis, from separare ‘disjoin, divide’ (see separate)

definitions: able to be separated or treated separately

examples.text: body and soul are not separable

shortDefinitions: able to be separated or treated separately

definitions: (of a German prefix) separated from the base verb when inflected.
shortDefinitions: (of German prefix) separated from base verb when inflected

definitions: (of a German verb) consisting of a prefix and a base verb that are separated when inflected, e.g., einführen.
shortDefinitions: (of German verb) consisting of prefix and base verb that are separated when inflected

definitions: (of an English phrasal verb) allowing the insertion of the direct object between the base verb and the particle, e.g., look it over as opposed to go over it.
shortDefinitions: (of English phrasal verb) allowing insertion of direct object between base verb and particle
